Detailed Description

Base Class for OnOffTools.

The OnOffTool class is a generic base class for all OnOffTool classes. It contains the functionality of an On/Off switch and also to find the state of the OnOffTool. The implementation for a specific OnOffTool is done in a derived class. For example, the DefaultOnOffTool class.

Example Program: 

//======================================================================== 
// Project: Robotic Platform
// ---------------------------------------------------------------------- 
// Package: End Effector Classes 
// Authors:   Vijayakrishna Basettihalli
// Start Date: Fri Jun 08 06:12:46 GMT 2001
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------  
// File: OnOffTool.t.cpp
// Example program for the class OnOffTool.
//========================================================================  
 

// ----- Standard Libaries -----
#include <iostream.h>
#include <conio.h>


// ----- QRTS Libraries -----

// ----- Project Includes -----
#include "RoboticPlatform.hpp"
#include "OnOffTool.hpp"
#include "ObjectManager.hpp"

//======================================================================== 
// main
//========================================================================  
 
int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
  RoboticPlatform::init(argc, argv);
  
  ObjectManager om;
  OnOffTool *onOffTool = om.createDerivedObject<OnOffTool>();


  if (onOffTool->d_objectStatus.isStatusError()) 
  {
    cout << onOffTool->d_objectStatus.getMessageText() << endl;
    return -1;
  }
  
  cout << "Menu: " << endl;
  cout << " \t[n] On" <<endl;
  cout << " \t[f] Off" <<endl;
  cout << " \t[q] Quit" <<endl;
  char ch;
  
  while ((ch=getch()) != 'q') 
  {
    if (ch=='n')
      onOffTool->on();
    else
      if (ch=='f')
        onOffTool->off();
      
  }
  
  RoboticPlatform::exit();            
  return 0;
}

bool isOn ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Determines if the OnOffTool is on.

Returns:
true: If the OnOffTool is on.
false: If the OnOffTool is off.
